With Bite.
From 30 Rockefeller Plaza in New York City, please enjoy this podcast edition of Late
Night with Seth Meyers. Today you'll hear Seth's chat with Andrea Mitchell of NBC News.
And just for this podcast, Mitchell stuck around to extend the conversation.
But first, a closer look.
The Trump White House continued to face the backlash today. Over presidents cruel and sudden
decision of ban transgender people from serving in the military. Meanwhile,
the Senate GOP was rushing to pass mystery legislation that could strip health care
away from millions of people. For more on this, it's time for a closer look.
As we all know, Donald Trump has cast himself as a champion of the working class. But throughout
his presidency, he's done very little to actually improve the lives of those working people.
He's either done needlessly cruel things that nobody asks for, like banning transgender soldiers,
or he's actively tried to make their lives worse by taking away their health care.
But Trump thinks he can get away with it because he's billed himself as a crusader against the
elites. So when new White House communications director Anthony Scaramucci did an interview with
the BBC this week, he was asked why Donald Trump is not himself an elite and gave an answer that
wasn't very commencing.
So what is this gonna happen?
Donald Trump is not the business side or the politics side or the inheritance side.
What part of Donald Trump? Many people in the UK don't understand that.
There's so many things about the president of the US.
He's a celebrity. He's a billionaire.
How about the pizza that we're-
Everyone eats cheeseburgers and pizza.
What are you talking about?
The Trump administration is so insane, even the British are getting flustered now.
And the British weren't even flustered by Dunkirk.
It's worth noting this interaction with the BBC went a little differently than the last time
Scaramucci spoke with the BBC in 2016 before he took a job with Trump.
When he told them that Donald Trump becomes the next president,
I'm looking forward to the BBC helping me find a flat somewhere in London.
And I have to say, I would have loved to see in the mooch living in London.
That would make a fantastic TV show. They could call it the Great British jerk-off.
Scaramucci was brought in as the White House communications director to get White House
communications back on track.
But last night, he called New Yorker reporter Ryan Lizah and unloaded
on fellow Trump staffers on the record. Now, this is a report that just came out.
Now, there is one word that we can't say on TV.
So instead, we're going to play the sound of a rooster, and you can figure out what word he was using.
Scaramucci claimed that Ryan's previous had leaked details of a dinner with Trump,
Fox News host Sean Hannity, and former Fox News exec Bill Shine.
According to the article, the issue he said was that he believed
previous had been worried about the dinner because he hadn't been invited.
Ryan says a f***ing paranoid schizophrenic. A paranoia, Scaramucci said.
He channeled previous as he spoke.
Oh, Bill Shine is coming in. Let me leak the f***ing thing and see if I can...
block these people the way I...
block Scaramucci for six months.
Previous did not respond to a request for comment.
But his comments on fellow White House officials Steve Bannon took the cake.
Scaramucci also told me that unlike other senior officials,
he had no interest in media attention.
I'm not Steve Bannon. I'm not trying to suck my own.
He said speaking of Trump's chief strategist.
I'm not trying to build my own brand off the f***ing strength of the president.
I'm here to serve the country Bannon declined to comment.
I'm guessing Bannon was unavailable to comment because based on his skill set,
he was otherwise engaged.
Or maybe he did comment and it was muffled, you know?
You know because of his...
But while this insane White House drama is playing out, Trump's policies are having real
consequences for real people. As you may recall during the campaign,
when Trump was cynically trying to drive a wedge between Hillary Clinton and Democratic voters,
he claimed that he would be the true champion of the LGBTQ community,
at one point even holding a gay pride flag at one of his events.
Look at him. He looks like a matador trying to make peace with a gay bull.
I don't want trouble.
Of course, it turns out when Trump claimed he supported the LGBTQ community,
he was just engaged in one of his favorite pastimes, aside from golfing,
lying. Although I'm pretty sure his favorite pastime is to lie in golf at the same time.
Let's see. One new tree and then water.
And then it was the tree again. Then I picked it up and threw it and it was puffed by pugs.
And then it went off the green and then I chipped it back.
I got a three.
The yesterday.
Yesterday revealed the scale of Trump's lies about his feelings towards the LGBTQ community.
When he announced via a tweet that he was banning transgender people from serving in the military,
our military must be focused on decisive and overwhelming victory and cannot be burdened
with the tremendous medical costs and disruption that transgender in the military would entail.
Okay. So clearly he didn't write that tweet.
That's way too many big words from a guy whose reading level can best be described as Tarzan.
But Trump's announcement apparently caught actual military officials off guard because he began his
announcement with this vague tweet. After consultation with my generals and military experts, please be
advised that the United States government will not accept or allow. And then he left that up by
itself for nine minutes. That's like if your girlfriend said, you know my new trainer Jeff and then
didn't say anything for nine minutes. The tweet was so vague it apparently caused panic at the
Defense Department. According to BuzzFeed, the Pentagon, the first of the three tweets raised
fears that the president was getting ready to announce strikes on North Korea or some other
military action. Many said they were left in suspense for nine minutes the time between the
first and second tweet. The Pentagon is afraid Trump might announce military action via tweet.
Let's pray he never tweets about his lunch. It's official. I just decided to nuke.
Two hot pockets in a B. Marita.
But as you might expect from a policy announcement tweet, it seems to have been rushed out
and poorly thought out. The White House could not provide answers to basic questions about how
the ban would work and whether it would affect current service members. So if you're wondering
why this decision seems so rushed and poorly thought out, that's because it has nothing to do
with military readiness. The fact is some of Trump's advisors like the super flexible I guess Steve
Bannon wanted to do things like this to appeal more to his base. In fact, it may be no coincidence
that according to the New York Times weeks ago, Bannon brought Ann Coulter, the fireman pundit,
to see Trump. Coulter railed at the president that he needed to focus more on his core supporters.
That's right. Trump met with Ann Coulter. Though technically you don't meet with Ann Coulter,
you get a mysterious videotape in the mail and then you put it in your VCR and then she climbs out
of your TV. But Trump isn't just busy inflicting needlessly cruelty on transgender people. He's
doing it to anyone who needs health care too. Because right now the GOP is rushing to vote on a bill
that would repeal and replace Obamacare by the end of the week. And we still don't know what they're
going to vote on. In fact, throughout this process, Republicans have been at a loss to explain to the
American people what they're trying to do here. What would their bill actually accomplish?
Scaramucci attempted to provide an answer yesterday, but I'm not sure it's going to comfort anyone.
What the president is trying to do is make the health care system freer. So why not disrupt and
decentralize the system, make it more price competitive, increase competition for the insurance companies,
and trust the process of the free market like in telecom, like in airlines. No one wants health
care to be like the airlines. How is the hospital? Not great. My surgery was three hours late. My
bed was double booked so they dragged me out of the OR. And then they sent my appendix to Albuquerque.
After getting over a procedural hurdle on Tuesday, Republicans in the Senate have failed to pass
several health care bills. One that would have only repealed Obamacare and one that would have
repealed and replaced it. Now, they're scrambling to come up with a third option. The GOP is basically
a drunk guy trying every key to get into his apartment. No, that's my mail key. I don't even
think this is my building. Scaramucci was asked why the process has been so difficult and used a
historical analogy that didn't quite add up. If you read Team of Rivals, it took Lincoln three or
four times to get what he wanted from the Senate and the House of Representatives,
which is the full abolition of slavery. That's right. Trump's team is just like Abraham Lincoln's
team of rivals. Who can forget Lincoln's stirring words denouncing slavery?
A house divided against itself cannot stand. I believe this government cannot endure half slave
and half free. And I also believe that my election victory was the biggest election victory of all
time. And no one believed I could do it. The fake news, the fake polls. Terrible people. Terrible
dishonest people. But we won. Oh, we won. All right. Isn't that right, Mooch? So now,
now, the GOP leaders scrambling to scrounge together the votes for some kind of new undisclosed plan,
Trump is personally going after Republicans who are bucking him, like Alaska Center Lisa Murkowski,
who voted no on Tuesday. And it's not just Trump going after his fellow Republicans who are against
this bill. Georgia GOP Congressman Buddy Carter was asked about Murkowski voting no, and he seemed
to threaten her with physical violence. What do you think about the president going after Lisa Murkowski
for her no vote yesterday on the motion to proceed? I think it's perfectly fair. Let me tell you,
somebody needs to go over there to that Senate and snap your knot in their ass.
Snatch a knot in their ass. Jesus. I guess when they drained the swamp, they found this guy floating at the bottom.
What does snatch a knot in their ass even mean? It's like a grand theft auto character who tried to say,
I'll pop a cap in your ass, but how to glitch. I'm going to snatch a knot in your head. Eat bread,
shopper. So now Republicans at the center are moving on to a third mystery plan. And just remember
how insane this is. They're trying to pass a bill that they've just come up with on the fly to
reorganize one sixth of the US economy and strip healthcare away from millions. Obamacare took 14
months, went through hundreds of hours of hearings and amendments from both parties. And at the time,
Republicans argued that that process was too secretive. Republicans like Mitch McConnell.
Americans are outraged by the last minute, closed door, sweetheart deals that were made to gain the
slimmest margin for passage of a bill that is all about their healthcare. They're pulling out all
the stops. They're doing everything they can to jam this bill through. And they don't even seem
to care anymore about how ugly it all looks. This is an incredibly unpopular bill. Thus,
their only rallying cry, make history. Ignore the American people. What an act of arrogance.
Why don't you all just, all you American people, all 300 million, obviously just sit down,
shut up, sit down. We'll do it for you. We'll restructure one sixth of the economy. We know what's
best for you. This is an act of total arrogance. Wow. It's rare to see Mitch McConnell get so angry.
Usually he just keeps all his rage stored up in his neck pouch.
That'll make me open that.
And now Trump is out there telling Republicans they need to make a decision. They don't have time
for hearings or debate or letting the American people know what's in the bill. Of course, back
in 2010, Republicans felt differently. Republicans like then-Congressman Mike Pence.
What's the hurry? I mean, the president says we got to bring it to a close. It's time to make
a decision. You know, the issue of healthcare and health insurance and the long-term cost of
healthcare is a profound issue that has enormous consequences, not only to the federal budget,
but to the most precious decisions of every American and every American family.
He says the time for talk is over. He spoke to that in the remarks saying that you guys on Capitol
Hill have been debating this. He said for decades and that, you know, the time for talk is over.
Yeah. Yeah. Well, and he says this isn't about politics, but why do we have to get it done
in two weeks? Man, look at Pence. That was seven years ago, and he looks the exact same.
Can we see his kindergarten photo? My God.
Of course, Republican objections back then were not in good faith, and neither is the process
they're using now. The things Trump and the GOP are doing right now are deeply unpopular,
so they're doing them in secret. And the words of the great Abraham Lincoln-
You can fool some of the people all of the time. And to keep the rest out, we're gonna build a wall!
This has been a closer look.
Hi, this is Fred Armisen, the music director of the HG band.
Did you know that late night with Seth Meyers has a podcast now? That's what this is.
And it's released every Wednesday and Friday. Tell your friends with a love late night that
they should subscribe at iTunes.com slash late night Seth. You'll find it. What I just said,
you'll be able to find it. I believe in you.
Our guest is an Emmy-winning journalist and the chief foreign
affairs correspondent for NBC News. She hosts Andrew Mitchell reports weekdays in noon on MSNBC.
Please welcome to the show, Andrew Mitchell, everybody!
Welcome to the show!
Thank you. It's so great to be at WOW.
Isn't it nice to see you because you have a show in the building?
Yeah.
But you don't have a live audience.
We don't have a live audience.
We've got cameras.
You've got cameras.
Yeah, well I know. I've seen the show.
But all these people come on down at noon.
So, okay. You've been doing this for a while.
You've been covering Washington for a while.
A lot of people say this is the most unprecedented time we're living in.
The last couple of days, voting on a healthcare bill that nobody knows what's in it.
Is this as unprecedented as we've been led to believe?
It's wild. It's crazy. I mean, nobody knows what they're voting on.
They don't know how much it's going to cost.
How many people are going to get knocked off of healthcare?
Who's going to get it? Who isn't going to get it?
They don't have a score from the budget office, the CBO, which is nonpartisan.
And so they're just going through these bills, trying to get something to say we didn't fail.
And while this is happening, and this is something that's going to affect so many people,
and so many people's health insurance, which is a big deal,
and then you have something like this morning where all of a sudden,
you know, he starts tweeting about how transgender people are not going to be allowed in the military.
I have heard that the Pentagon was completely taken by surprise by this.
Is that what you're reporting us led to?
It's a little scary that the Pentagon, you know, U.S. intelligence did not know that the
President was going to change the policy for trans people.
And I don't think that the Defense Secretary knew he is away on vacation for a couple of days.
We've got a lot of big military issues if Afghanistan...
Do you think he spoke to the generals? I know he was saying that.
Is that something that we can be led to believe is true?
I don't know. Yeah.
Can't say.
But the fact is that the generals have other big things.
Afghanistan, Syria, you know, how to deal with North Korea,
whether missiles are going to go up as early as tonight or tomorrow.
I mean, there...
Those are reallys tonight.
Yeah, maybe.
Well, I hope they wait till after this airs.
I'd love to get one more in.
And then, do...
I mean, you know, there's a lot of theorists floating around.
Do you think that this is something, an issue that is near and dear to his heart,
or that he's playing to his base, or that he's using it to distract from the health care issue
that people talk about less when he does a tweet about transgender soldiers?
It's hard to say what's going on in his mind, and what, you know, what he's thinking.
I mean, seriously, I mean, I can't interpret it, but it certainly has been a distraction
from the failure on health care.
It does play to the base.
It's a social issue, and it contradicts completely what he said during the campaign.
So it's hard to figure out that this is near and dear to him,
if it's not something he was talking about when he was running for office.
You, one of the things covering foreign policy, you have to cover the Secretary of State,
Rex Tillerson. He has not been taking a lot of questions. Would you say this is the least?
In your time, there's never been a Secretary of State that's been had a lot less access.
Absolutely.
And you've tried very hard, very noble efforts. Here you are,
asking him some questions at the end of a photo op. Let's take a look real quick.
Mr. Secretary, China has said there will be consequences for the deployment now of anti-missile
defenses in South Korea.
Mr. Minister, are you sure that from the administration will be strong against Vladimir Putin?
Thank you, guys.
Thank you.
Can you assure us that Russia will not be able to move further in Ukraine?
We haven't had any time in here.
I mean, that is humiliating.
Yeah. You looked like a woman who was lost in a shopping mall, the other.
Also, it's that interesting when people say thank you and you get the sense they're not that
thankful.
And, you know, the other thing is he is not letting the press fly with him.
And here is a guy who was taking trips to obviously everywhere across the globe.
And so you have to, the press has to fly commercial to try to catch up with him.
Has that been made at your job even harder?
Well, it's impossible because you cannot fly from here to there, from country to country
without a military plane. I don't have one.
You know, we pay our way on this.
So this is not a budget issue.
They say it's a budget issue, but he doesn't want to have the press go around.
So he has one person with him, one person from the media now that he sort of represents all of us.
But the fact is that for decades now, secretaries of state have briefed us on the plane or had their
top officials briefing us. He doesn't have that many top officials because they haven't filled
the vacancies, which is another issue.
But it really is hurting American diplomacy.
It's not good for us as a country to not have the press able to say, well, this is what the goal is
of this administration or this secretary. It also sends a really bad signal, I think,
to regimes in China, in Turkey, in Russia, where reporters don't only not get press conferences,
they get locked up, they get killed. I mean, there has always been a tradition where the U.S.
secretary of state, Republicans and Democrats bring the press corps along, and if they don't
have press conferences there, he or she will hold a press conference to show that we believe in
freedom of the press.
That is very disturbing. I mentioned you've been doing this a long time, and you are sort of a
trailblazer as a female journalist. And very early on, you noticed a bit of the distinction
that people in charge will make between female and male reporters. You covered Three Mile Island,
which was obviously a big story. And what was your beat that you were in charge of Three Mile Island?
I covered energy. I was the NBC Energy correspondent, so I covered nuclear energy.
And this was a potential meltdown, so it was on my watch.
And so what happened when you tried to go report from Three Mile Island?
Well, a very kindly paternalistic bureau chief, a lovely man, said, when I noticed that five days
in, I was the only correspondent not going in and covering this thing.
I went and said, how come I'm the only one who's not going to Three Mile Island?
And he said, because you are a woman of childbearing age.
Wow. And I said, has it occurred to you that men's balls are as vulnerable to radiation
women's over?
You had great.
That's right.
That's right.
It's very...
I mean, I got there the next day.
They said it right now.
Also, I want to say that's very noble because for all the doors that weren't open to women for so long,
the one that you would think they'd be happy to have closed is the door to Three Mile Island.
But you...
I think that speaks to a lot to the integrity you have as a journalist.
And please keep up the good work, Andrew. It's just lovely having you here.
Thank you.
And your Mitchell, everybody. Andrew Mitchell reports there's weekdays and news on the other side of the scene.
Everybody, this is Henry from Late Night. I'm here with Andrew Mitchell.
When I talk to journalists here, I'm always interested in how they get their news while
they're also kind of reporting news during the day. What is your day like, because you're always
reporting, always on air, working sources, etc.
I'm following social media. I'm also... I've got all the cables up and following anything that's
breaking from major print sources and also watching White House briefings, watching the hill.
So we get feeds of everything that's going on on Capitol Hill at the State Department,
the Pentagon, any briefings that take place.
Right.
And calling sources.
So you're on the air at noon. You also work on many other shows.
But I feel like you're also the person that MSNBC or NBC goes to when there's a breaking
foreign story. Like you'd be going out at Andrew Mitchell's. You'd like you must just be running
to the studio so often outside of your regularly scheduled hours.
And that's partly because there's just so much news. I mean, there's so much happening.
Cable and social media and all of the technology that has transformed our
business has meant that we're working 24-7. All of us are.
Yeah.
And this president is so active on social media.
That's true.
That you never know when something's going to hit.
Yeah. I wanted to ask you, you mentioned out there with Seth that there are all these vacancies
across the government. Can you talk about where the vacancies are and how damaging that is to the
United States?
It's enormously damaging. They only have 50 confirmed people out of almost 600 slots around
the government that need to be filled. And in many cases, people are just not even nominated yet.
It's not waiting for the FBI clearances. But it's not really stalled for the most part by any kind
of political interference on the Hill. It's basically that they weren't ready coming out of this
transition. Yeah.
You know, they fired Chris Christie from the transition. They started from scratch.
And they come into government with someone like Mike Flynn, not vetted properly. In 28 days,
he's gone. Yeah.
And national security advisor. And you've got in the Pentagon in particular and at the State
Department vacancies everywhere, assistant secretaries. So you've got all these fill-in people who are
holdovers who are not trusted enough to be policymakers or to be given insight into what the policy is.
Right. So your secretary of state is basically home alone. He's got a deputy now,
but no undersecretaries and no acting secretaries.
When you talk to your sources outside of the United States, what are they saying about this
thin American government? I've talked to heads of state and ambassadors and they say there's no one
to call. Wow.
And so a lot of them during the transition say they did call Jared Kushner to try to get through
to set up appointments. We'll now diplomat Jared Kushner.
Right. Real estate, son of real estate mogul, 30 something, whatever.
That's the point person.
And he is actually now also the point person for Middle East diplomacy.
And for, you know, reinventing government.
Mm-hmm. Transportation.
Transportation.
And I guess now interviews on Capitol Hill.
Stunning. I also wanted to ask you about your strategy to get questions answered. We saw the clip
of you trying to get an answer out of Secretary of State Rex Tillerson.
But over your career, you've had different strategies to make sure people hear you and answer your question.
Well, first of all, I guess I am loud, but I'm sure. And so it's very hard if you're behind the
cameras for anyone to see when you're as short as I am a 5'3". But so I used to crawl under the
tripods and pop up on the other side and, you know, Mr. President, Mr. President wave at Ronald Reagan
who tried to get him to stop because he often did stop and talk on the way out to the helicopter.
And so when presidents aren't having news conferences, you start shouting at
press conference, at photo opportunities, my mother used to chastise me saying that
she didn't raise me to be this rude.
Ha-ha-ha-ha.
But it's a balance of being a reporter. You have to be confrontational. There has to be a
confrontational kind of relationship. But as a person, it also must be odd because you want to be...
It's very odd.
Yeah.
Yeah.
I'm kind of... No one who knows me would believe this, who's seen me shouting and pushing and
climbing over chairs to get to Hillary Clinton on a roll-fog because she hasn't had a news
conference yet in six months. But the fact is I'm kind of shy and I wish people would like me.
You know, I kind of want to be friendly, but there's something that gets triggered when
a politician is avoiding answering important questions that gets me into gear.
Well, thank you for doing what you do. It's great to be with you.
It was such a pleasure. It was so fun.
So great. Thank you, Andrew.
Thank you.
You can find something that gives you a little insight.
From Wondery, I love my kid, but shares hilarious stories and anecdotes about parenting that are
actually relatable. Like when a friend asks you to do something at 6 p.m. on a weeknight.
Here's a clip from an episode.
Is dinner three hours at your house?
I noticed that when I have company over and we have a dinner party, that is about the time.
Oh, okay.
And I really want everyone to leave no later than 6 30 or 7.
So and only the people without kids are like kind of clueless.
And I'm like, you don't understand like it's bedtime now and it is, you don't want to see this.
You don't want to see this.
And I don't want you to see this.
Some horrors are about to have it.
They are the boss. She is the boss of us.
And I don't want you to see that.
Listen to I love my kid, but on the Wondery app or wherever you get your podcasts,
you can listen to I love my kid, but early and ad-free on Wondery Plus.
